DOC.HEAD: Communist Premier Backs Havel for President in Czechoslovakia
Eds: LEADS with nine grafs, UPDATING with parliament approves broad economic and political reforms. Picks up 7th, `The presidency ...
LaserPhoto XPRA2
DOC.TEXT: Communist Premier Marian Calfa endorsed opposition leader Vaclav Havel for president Tuesday, signaling a major victory for the peaceful pro-democracy revolution led by the playwright-activist. Parliamentary leaders met after a session of the Communist-dominated Federal Assembly and agreed to reconvene it on Dec. 29 to elect a new president. The meeting will be held at Hradcany Castle, the presidential residence. Parliament late Tuesday also unanimously approved a new government program outlining broad political and economic reforms, including proposals to guarantee freedom of assembly and association and freedom of religion. The program also calls for movement from a state-run economy toward a free market system but no further details were immediately available. Josef Bartoncik, head of the lower house and leader of the People's Party, said his party would support Havel and that ``the election would be in the interest of all citizens of our country.'' The Socialists _ like the People's Party one of four small parties in parliament _ also announced Tuesday it would support Havel. In a speech to the Communist-dominated parliament, Calfa, urged the deputies to elect a new president by the end of the year. ``It is the government's opinion that there is no alternative . .. than to elect Vaclav Havel as president,'' Calfa said. He said the presidency should be filled at once in the ``interest of stability.'' The presidency in Czechoslovakia is a largely ceremonial post, but it has great symbolic importance because of the respect the country's first president, Tomas Masaryk, enjoyed in the independent Czechoslovakia he founded in 1918. Calfa said the new president should serve only until June or July, when Czechoslovakia is to hold its first free elections in 43 years. Havel, whose works were banned when the uprising against rigid Communist rule began a month ago, has said he would serve as president only on an interim basis, until a replacement was chosen by a democratically elected parliament. Havel was in prison as recently as May, when he completed a four-month sentence on protest-related charges. Jockeying over the presidency has dominated politics for nearly two weeks, after a series of stunning opposition triumphs forced the Communists to relinquish their monopoly on power and name the first government since 1948 not dominated by the party. Calfa's endorsement of Havel was an unprecedented show of support. His government has been reported trying to overcome resistance among Communist deputies to Havel's candidacy. Czechoslovakia has not had a president since Dec. 10, when Gustav Husak, a member of the old guard, resigned after swearing in the new government. Husak's resignation followed a series of leadership changes that removed hard-line leaders associated with the crackdown after the Warsaw Pact invasion that ended the ``Prague Spring'' reforms of 1968 led by Alexander Dubcek. Dubcek, later dismissed as party chief and assigned to an obscure forestry job in Bratislava, also has been mentioned as a potential presidential candidate. The Communist Party has been in disarray since a brutal police crackdown on student protesters Nov. 17 started the anti-Communist revolution. A two-day special party congress opens Wednesday in Prague, and is expected to recommend more personnel and policy changes.
